Tyson Prepared Foods, North Richland Hills

Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary



I. Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies



It is the policy of Tyson Foods Inc. to implement a Risk Management Plan (RMP) in accordance with 40 CFR Part 68. Included in this process is the implementation of OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.119.



The purpose of implementing these programs is to prevent the release of anhydrous ammonia. By doing so we protect employees and guests on site while protecting the general public off site. 



As part of these programs, Tyson Foods has developed an emergency response plan that includes a well-trained response team that coordinates closely with local fire department and other off site emergency personnel.



II. The stationary source and regulated substance



The food production process at this facility requires very low temperatures in order to process and maintain the finished product. The refrigeration system uses anhydrous ammonia to provide the proper temperature in the production areas, coolers and blast freezers. 



III. General accident release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention.



A. Tyson Prepared Foods, North Richland Hills has designed and implemented a preventative maintenance program to reduce the potential for release of ammonia from the refrigeration system. This program complies with the requirements of OSHA regulation 29 CFR 1910.119 Process Safety Management. The key concept of this release prevention program is employee participation, appropriate design and maintenance of equipment and appropriate training of all Tyson Team Members.



The PSM Team is responsible for conducting and implementing findings from the PHA Process Hazard Analysis for the ammonia system. Team members are also members of the facility emergency response team. This ER Team has developed an Emergency Response Plan which includes specific procedures and equipment to allow the safe response to an ammonia leak or

release. These procedures are designed to minimize a leak or release.



The list below identifies individuals with specific responsibilities in the prevention and response plans.



B. Lines of Authority and Responsibility in RMP



Terry Patton: Plant Manager



Responsible for all regulatory affairs within the plant.  The Plant Manager delegates program responsibilities to individuals in the facility depending on individual roles and job descriptions.  



Derek Senter:  Complex Environmental Manager



The Complex Environmental Mgr. is responsible for oversight of all environmental programs including the Risk Management Program.  The day-to-day management of the PSM and RMP programs however is the duty of the PSM coordinator.  



Marte Amrine: Maintenance Manager 



The Maintenance Mgr. is responsible for Maintenance, Repair, and Refrigeration systems at the facility.  The Maintenance Manager is the direct supervisor of the Maintenance Superintendent whom the Process Safety and Risk Management Programs have been delegated.  



: Refrigeration Superintendent



The Maintenance Superintendent has the responsibility of ensuring the PSM/RMP elements are properly implemented by the Refrigeration Superintendent. The Refrigeration Superintendent is responsible for refrigeration staff and all refrigeration operations, maintenance of refrigeration equipment. This position has management oversight over all refrigeration staff. The Refrigeration Superintendent ensures all equipment in the refrigeration system is maintained in proper working order.





Cody Murray: PSM Coordinator



This position also serves as the PSM Coordinator.  This position is responsible for implementation and maintenance of the Process Safety and Risk Management Prevention Program documentation, including but not limited to Mechanical Integrity, Management of Change, Training, Operating Procedures, Incident Investigation and Emergency Response.  



Refrigeration Operator Staff



The Refriger

ation staff act in a supporting role for Process Safety and Risk Management and as operators of the refrigeration system.  Day-to-day operations include but are not limited to performing operational checks on refrigeration equipment, completion and maintenance of equipment logs, preventive maintenance, and pre-operational inspections.  



Peter Bernard: Safety Manager



The Safety Manager is responsible for development and implementation of safety policies and procedures at the plant site.  The Safety Manager shall work side by side with the Refrigeration Supervisor to ensure all refrigeration staff are provided with proper personal protective equipment and enforcement that it is worn when appropriate.  This position is also responsible for Contractor Safety program, Hot Work permits and updates to the emergency response program.  The Safety Manager also supports the Hazmat team to ensure all personnel and equipment remain fully functional and available at all times for emergency response.



IV. Five-year accident history



There have not been any releases of anhydrous ammonia at this facility in the last five years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant damage on site or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 



V. Emergency Response Program



As part of these programs, Tyson Foods has developed an emergency response plan that includes a well-trained response team that coordinates closely with local fire department and other off site emergency personnel.



VI. Planned changes to improve safety



Our plan is to continue to add highly skilled refrigeration mechanics to our staff. We are also providing skills training to the team members we now have on staff.
